description.narrative:
Kvinna till Kvinna har ansökt om Sida- finansiering motsvarande 16 080 907 SEK för att förlänga sitt program ’Building Women's Movements in Iraq 2011-2013’ under perioden 2014-2015 (förlängningsansökan daterad 2014-03-31).
Initiativet syftar till att bidra till att stärka respekten för de mänskliga rättigheterna, genom att stärka kvinnors organisering, kvinnoorganisationers kapacitet och effektivitet.
Programmet genomförs i samarbete med sex till åtta irakiska kvinnoorganisationer. Kvinna till Kvinna bidrar till kapacitetsuppbyggnad, nätverksarbete, institutionellt stöd och projektfinansiering till sina partners. Partnerorganisationer är verksamma i olika verksamhetsområden med sina respektive projekt, gemensamt arbete fokuserar på våld mot kvinnor.

Kvinna till Kvinna has applied for Sida funding, amounting to 16,080,907 SEK, in order to to continue the program "Building Women's Movements in Iraq 2011-2013" during 2014 and 2015.
The intervention aims at strengthening the respect for women's human rights by enhancing women's organization 'organizational capacity and outreach. Kvinna till Kvinna will implement the program by supporting eight to ten organizations.

sector.narrative: Women’s rights organisations and movements, and government institutions

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2016Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: Kvinna till Kvinna's (KtK) program "Building Women's Movements in Iraq" was implemented from July 2011 to March 2016 with a total contribution from Sida of 42 249 451 SEK.
As a result of the program, KtK's partner organizations have improved their capacity to work with and advocate for women's human rights at several levels. The partner organizations carry out the day to day work to build awareness for women's human rights, provide protection and support women survivors as well as active networking and advocacy on both a national and an international arena to fight for reforms, laws and approval of resolutions and conventions. The partner organisations have contributed both individually on the local level and jointly on the national and international level.
For example, the partner organizations' joint advocacy actions together with other Iraqi women's rights organisations led to that the Jafaari law, which contained several provisions that violate the rights of women and children, was not approved by the parliament; to the approval of the National Action Plan on the UNSCR 1325 by the government and also to the renewal on the commitment to implement the National Action Plan that was expressed by the President in the end of 2015.
The advocacy at the international level increased in the last year of the program when the partner organizations have presented information and recommendations and reached foreign embassies, international institutions and decision makers in the European Union institutions.
The organizations have also improved their financial and management systems and thus build more sustainable organizational structures.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
